title: Detect a Phone Virus on Samsung Galaxy: Signs, Scans, & More

steps.title: Check for increased data usage.
steps.content: Check for increased data usage. Viruses often use your phone or tablet’s data plan while running in the background. This may cause sudden spikes in data usage. Check your billing statement for abnormal charges from increased data usage.

steps.title: Analyze your bank account for unexplained charges.
steps.content: Analyze your bank account for unexplained charges. Some viruses may make purchases or download apps without your knowledge.

steps.title: Look for apps you didn’t download.
steps.content: Look for apps you didn’t download. If you see an app icon on the home screen or in the app drawer that you don’t recall downloading, it could be the work of a virus. Even if the app looks legitimate, use caution if you don’t remember downloading it.

steps.title: Watch for frequently crashing apps.
steps.content: Watch for frequently crashing apps. If an app that never caused any problems in the past begins crashing frequently, a virus could be the reason.

steps.title: Pay attention to pop-up ads.
steps.content: Pay attention to pop-up ads. Pop-ups might not seem out of the ordinary while browsing the web. However, when you’re suddenly inundated by pop-ups, your Galaxy may have an infection. Whatever you do, do not tap on any links in pop-up ads. This could make things worse.

steps.title: Monitor your battery usage.
steps.content: Monitor your battery usage. Since viruses run constantly in the background, your Galaxy may need more frequent charging. If you use used to charge the Galaxy every 2 or 3 days but suddenly have to charge every day, a virus could be the culprit.

steps.title: Run a security scan.
steps.content: Run a security scan. Your Galaxy comes with its own security application, but you can use any you prefer. See Running a Security Scan to check your phone or tablet for viruses.

steps.title: Open your Galaxy’s Settings.
steps.content: Open your Galaxy’s Settings. To do this, swipe down from the top of the home screen, then tap the gear icon at the top-right corner.

steps.title: Tap Device security.
steps.content: Tap Device security . It’s the shield icon at the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Tap SCAN PHONE.
steps.content: Tap SCAN PHONE . The security app will now scan your Galaxy for viruses and other malware.

steps.title: Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the process.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the process. If the app finds anything suspicious, it will report the steps you must take to correct the situation.
